section.title: MSS for JBoss Clustering and Failover Support
section.para: Mobicents supports the clustering of SIP Servlets Servers for performance, reliability and failover purposes. Note that only SIP Servlets-customized JBoss Application Servers can be used as cluster nodes: there is no support for SIP Servlets-enabled Tomcat Containers.

As the Mobicents SIP Servlets Server employs the JBoss Application Server as its servlet container and takes advantage of its capabilities, including clustering and failover, it is also helpful to be familiar with the basics of JBoss Clustering, which are documented in the JBoss Application Server Clustering Guide.

section.title: SIP Servlets Server Cluster: Installing, Configuring and Running

varlistentry.term: A SIP Servlets-enabled JBoss Application Server

listitem.para: Before proceeding, you should follow the instructions for installing, configuring, running and testing a SIP Servlets-enabled JBoss Application Server from the binary distribution:

The easiest way to set up a cluster of SIP Servlets-enabled JBoss Application Servers is to install, configure and test the binary distribution on one machine, and then simply copy the entire installation to the other machines—nodes—in the cluster. This is the approach taken in this chapter.

section.title: Configuring
section.para: Once installed, the SIP Servlets-enabled JBoss AS binary distribution requires only minor configuration in order to enable clustering. SIP and HTTP session statue clustering are already set up and ready-to-go. However, to enable session replication in your node, you must tag it as <distributable/> in the web.xml descriptor.

important.title: You Must Use the all Server Configuration Profile
important.para: You will notice that the following instructions modify one or more properties in the configuration files for the all Server Configuration Profile. This is evident in the path names given below. When we run the SIP Servlets-enabled JBoss AS nodes, we will invoke run.sh (or run.bat) with the -c all option, which will activate the server's clustering capabilities. The server will then consult the configuration files under the <topmost_directory>/server/all/ directory, and not in the the <topmost_directory>/server/default/ subdirectories. Therefore, it is important to modify the correct files.

section.para: To do so, open the web.xml configuration file, which lives in the <topmost_directory>/server/all/deploy/jboss-web.deployer/conf/ directory, and add the empty element <distributable/> as a child of the document root element, web-app:

example.title: Enabling Node Session Replication in the web.xml Deployer
example.programlisting:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?><?xml version="1.0" encoding="ISO-8859-1"?> <web-app xmlns="http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/j2ee" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/j2ee http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/j2ee/web-app_2_4.xsd" version="2.4">
<!-- ======================== Introduction ============================== --> <!-- This document defines default values for *all* web applications --> <!-- loaded into this instance of Tomcat. As each application is --> <!-- deployed, this file is processed, followed by the --> <!-- "/WEB-INF/web.xml" deployment descriptor from your own --> <!-- applications. --> <!-- --> <!-- WARNING: Do not configure application-specific resources here! --> <!-- They should go in the "/WEB-INF/web.xml" file in your application. -->
<!-- =========== Common Context Params ================================== --> <!-- JBossInjectionProvider provides resource injection for managed beans. --> <!-- See JSF 1.2 spec section 5.4 for details. -->
<distributable/>
<context-param> <param-name>com.sun.faces.injectionProvider</param-name> <param-value>org.jboss.web.jsf.integration.injection.JBossInjectionProvider</param-value> </context-param>

section.para: For further information on enabling session replication in your SIP Servlets-enabled JBoss Application Server, refer to Enabling session replication in your application in the JBoss Application Server Getting Started Guide.

section.title: Running
